bad.work: Six Extra-Illustrations to a Second Folio Edition of Shakespeare

title.reg: Six Extra-Illustrations to a Second Folio Edition of Shakespeare

titlestmt.title: Six Extra-Illustrations to a Second Folio Edition of Shakespeare : electronic edition
titlestmt.principal: Editors: Morris Eaves, University of Rochester; Robert Essick, University of California, Riverside; and Joseph Viscomi, University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill

filedesc.extent: 1 XML file approx. 20KB; 2 JPEG (ISO/IEC 10918) files ranging in size from 92KB to 1100KB
filedesc.publicationstmt: Chapel Hill: Eaves, Essick, Viscomi; UNC LibrariesMarch 2020
filedesc.updatestmt:
The William Blake Archive is pleased to announce the publication of a digital edition of Blake’s water color illustrations to the plays of William Shakespeare.
Although less extensive and well known than his illustrations of John Milton’s poems, Blake’s water colors based on Shakespeare’s plays constitute a significant group of designs. The earliest, dating from c. 1779, is probably one of Blake’s illustrations of English history but nonetheless evokes Shakespeare’s King Lear. The series of seven small ovals picturing characters from the plays also dates from Blake’s early years. The concentrated focus on just one or two figures filling most of the pictorial space may be Blake’s response to popular interest in miniature portraiture. The reason for his execution of this group is not known; like the English history designs, they may have been intended for eventual publication as engravings. The series of Shakespeare character portraits by John Hamilton Mortimer, published as engravings in the mid-1770s, may have influenced Blake’s similar project.
Oberon, Titania and Puck with Fairies Dancing is one of Blake’s largest water colors of the 1780s. Its size and quality suggest that it may have been intended for exhibition, like the water colors illustrating the life of Joseph displayed at the Royal Academy in 1785. The circle of dancers and Puck’s stance with arms raised echo similar motifs in George Romney’s Leveson-Gower Family, painted in 1776-77 and published as a mezzotint by John Raphael Smith in 1781.
Blake was clearly attracted to the vision of Queen Katherine in Henry VIII, act 4, scene 2, for he executed four versions beginning c. 1783-90 and concluding with the highly finished and complex water color of c. 1825-26. Blake’s water color of Queen Katherine’s dream dated 1809 is part of a series of six illustrations to Shakespeare’s plays commissioned by Joseph Thomas, the clergyman who had earlier employed Blake to illustrate Milton’s Comus and Paradise Lost. In a letter of 31 July 1801 to William Hayley, John Flaxman added a postscript to Blake, including the following: “he [Thomas] also desired you [Blake] will make two designs in bister or Indian Ink, from Shakespeare’s Troylus & Cressida, Coriolanus, either of the 3 plays of Henry 6.th Richard the 3.d or Henry the 8.th each design for one play for which he will give a Guinea each, the dimensions as follow the paper. an upright square of 12 Inches & half by 8 Inches, within this Space leaving a moderate margin, the principal figure not exceeding 6 Inches high” (Butlin 547). Blake’s designs (most now trimmed) roughly follow these size requirements, necessitated by Thomas’s desire to create an extra-illustrated copy of the 1632 second folio of Shakespeare’s plays, but Blake waited eight years before completing the commission, changed the medium from monochrome drawings to water colors, and illustrated only two plays, Richard III and Henry VIII, specified by Flaxman. Blake may have chosen the other passages for illustration, at some point convincing Thomas of their appropriateness.
Many of Blake’s Shakespeare designs show his predilection for scenes dealing with perceptions that extend beyond the world of the physical senses. The four versions of Queen Katherine’s dream epitomize this lifelong interest in imaginative and visionary experiences. A corollary is Blake’s attraction to representations of the arts, demonstrated by Oberon, Titania and Puck with Fairies Dancing and his portrayal of Pegasus, the classical embodiment of poetic inspiration, in As If an Angel Dropped Down from the Clouds among the designs for Thomas.
As always, the William Blake Archive is a free site, imposing no access restrictions and charging no subscription fees. The site is made possible by the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill with the University of Rochester, the continuing support of the Library of Congress, and the cooperation of the international array of libraries and museums that have generously given us permission to reproduce works from their collections in the Archive.
Morris Eaves, Robert N. Essick, and Joseph Viscomi, editors
Joseph Fletcher, managing editor, Michael Fox, assistant editor
The William Blake Archive

objtitle.title: *Six Extra-Illustrations to a Second Folio Edition of Shakespeare*

objdescid.compdate: 1806 and 1809Objects 1 (*Jacques and the Wounded Stag*), 4 (*Brutus and Caesar's Ghost*), and 5 (*Hamlet and His Father's Ghost*) are inscribed by Blake with the date "1806." Objects 3 (*Queen Katharine's Dream*) and 6 (*As If an Angel Dropped Down from the Clouds*) are inscribed "1809" by Blake. Object 2 (*Richard III and the Ghosts*) can be dated to c. 1806 because of its stylistic similarities to the works with that inscribed date.

objinfo.leafsize: approximately 24.5 x 18.0 cm. (objects 1, 2, 4, 5), 30.8 x 19.4 cm. (object 3), 38.0 x 19.1 cm. (object 6)
objinfo.medium: pen and ink and water colorBlake's inscriptions are in pen and ink.
objinfo.framelines: Single framing lines extend around objects 3 and 6.

provenance.name: British Museum
provenance.note: In part commissioned from Blake by Joseph Thomas in 1801 (see the postscript addressed to Blake in John Flaxman's letter of 31 July 1801 to William Hayley, quoted in Butlin 547) but apparently not delivered until 1806-09 when inserted into a 1632 second folio of Shakespeare's plays; by inheritance to Thomas's widow in 1811; their daughter, Mrs. John Woodford Chase; her son, Drummond Percy Chase, in 1876, probably by inheritance; sold 1880 to Alexander Macmillan; W. E. F. Macmillan; given by the executors of his estate to the British Museum in 1954.

repository.addressline: Email, Department of Prints and Drawings: prints@britishmuseum.org

desc.objtitle: Jacques and the Wounded Stag, Object 1 (Butlin 547.1)

illustration.illusobjdesc: In this illustration of Shakespeare's As You Like It, a male figure sits on the bank of a body of water and turns his head to look up with an open mouth. His left arm is bent upward with palm facing up. He extends his right arm to point toward a deer at left, which appears to be wounded and dripping blood from its left side. The animal bends down, perhaps to drink from the water. At least eight other deer are visible in the forested background. The man is Jacques, one of the noblemen attending Duke Senior who lives in exile in the forest. In Act II, Scene I, of the play, the First Lord narrates a story about observing "melancholy Jacques" as he followed a wounded stag to the edge of a stream and, while overcome with emotion, compared the animal's isolation and death to the ills of human society: "'Poor deer,' quoth he, 'thou mak'st a testament/ As worldlings do, giving thy sum of more/ To that which had too much.'" (49-51).

component.illusobjdesc: In this illustration of Shakespeare's As You Like It, a male figure sits on the bank of a body of water and turns his head to look up with an open mouth. He has short hair (perhaps partially bald?) and a mustache and wears a collared shirt, pants, and perhaps sandals. His left arm is bent upward with palm facing up. He extends his right arm and may point toward a deer at left, which appears to be wounded. The male figure represents Jacques, one of the noblemen attending Duke Senior who lives in exile in the forest. In Act II, Scene I, of the play, the First Lord narrates a story about observing "melancholy Jacques" as he followed a wounded stag to the edge of a stream and, while overcome with emotion, compared the animal's isolation and death to the ills of human society.

A stag with prominent antlers bends forward, possibly to drink from a body of water on the left side of this illustration of Shakespeare's As You Like It. The animal faces forward, and tears stream down from its eyes. A wound is visible on its left side from which blood drips and to which the male figure, Jacques, points. The scene references Jacques' interaction with a wounded, crying stag in Act II, Scene I of the play in which he compares the isolation and eventual death of the animal to the ills of human society. "The wretched animal heaved forth such groans/ That their discharge did stretch his leathern coat/ Almost to bursting, and the big round tears/ Coursed one another down his innocent nose/ In piteous chase." (37-41).

In this illustration of Shakespeare's As You Like It, at least eight deer are visible in the forested background: a group of three stand facing forward between two trees at left while a cluster of five appear to run to the right or away near the center of the image. All of these animals have antlers and are thus stags. These deer likely represent the "careless herd,/ Full of pasture, [who] jumps along by him [the wounded deer]/ And never stays to greet him." (55-57).

A body of water and a grassy bank (on which the male figure sits) are visible along the bottom edge of the image from which the stag prepares to drink. The water is likely the "brook that brawls along this wood;/ To the which place a poor sequestered stag/ That from the hunter's aim had ta'en a hurt/ Did come to languish." (33-35).

This illustration likely represents the forest in which Duke Senior and his noblemen attendants, including Jacques, live in exile in Shakespeare's play As You Like It. Four tree trunks with leafy foliage dominate the grassy, hilly landscape. Branches are visible on the two middle trees, and a leafy vine (perhaps ivy) grows up the leftmost tree, which is likely the oak "whose antique root peeps out" mentioned in the play (32).
Below an area of blue sky upper left, hills are visible in the background forested landscape, with one particularly large hill behind the group of deer at left.

lg.note: Butlin 547.1 records additional inscriptions, but we have not been able to locate these on the work as it presently exists.

desc.objtitle: Richard III and The Ghosts, Object 2 (Butlin 547.2)

illustration.illusobjdesc: A central figure in armor raises a sword above his head while at least nine other figures, who are translucent and thus likely ghosts, hover around him. The illustration likely represents the scene from Shakespeare's play Richard III, Act 5, Scene 3, in which King Richard III is visited in his tent by the ghosts of all those he has killed, including his brother, nephews, and wife. Only nine of the play's eleven ghosts, however, are depicted here. Facing forward in the center of the composition with sword raised, Richard leans or steps to the left with legs spread wide. He looks up with a fearful expression, and his mouth is open. Directly below him, two small translucent figures hover or fly with heads at left, facing up. They both have short hair and appear to wear gowns; both point upward toward Richard. They are likely the ghosts of Prince Edward and Richard, Duke of York, the sons of late King Edward IV. Four additional ghostly figures hover near the right margin. Facing away but turned to look left, a female figure with a long gown and veil extends her left arm to touch Richard on the shoulder. Her mouth is open, suggesting she is speaking. This figure is likely the Ghost of Lady Anne, Richard's wife whom he murdered in order to court his niece, Elizabeth of York. Immediately behind and to the left of Lady Anne, an older male figure with a mustache and long beard faces forward and looks down to the left toward Richard. He bends his right arm to point toward Anne. The heads of two additional ghostly figures appear alternatively to the left of the bearded male figure and to the right of the female figure, Anne. On the left side of the image, three additional ghostly male figures appear, all facing right. The rightmost of these is bearded and wears a crown and a long gown. His mouth is open and his brow furrowed as he points accusingly toward bloody wounds in his chest with both bent arms. This is likely King Henry VI, who in the play tells Richard III, "When I was mortal, my annointed body/ By thee was punched full of deadly holes./ Think on the Tower and me. Despair and die!" (132-134). The middle male figure at left has short curly hair and appears to look down in horror at the wounds of the male figure in front of him, King Henry VI. Only the head of the leftmost figure, whose mouth is open, is visible. Behind the figures, the top of a tent is visible; in the play, the ghosts visit Richard in his battlefield tent on the eve of war. There is a bed with sheets and a tubular pillow (?) in the lower part of the composition's background along with a table on which two lighted candles and an open book rest. Areas of dark shadow appear all around the composition, and the areas of darkness in the upper corners of the composition may suggest the time is night.

component.illusobjdesc: Facing forward in the center of the composition with sword raised above his head with his bent right arm, a male figure leans or steps to the left with legs spread wide and left leg extended. He has short curly hair and a beard and also wears armor. His left arm is bent and by his side where he holds a scabbard. He looks up with a fearful expression, and his mouth is open. At least nine other figures, who are translucent and thus likely ghosts, hover around him. The illustration likely represents the scene from Shakespeare's play Richard III, Act 5, Scene 3, in which King Richard III is visited in his tent by the ghosts of all those he has killed, including his brother, nephews, and wife.
The central figure, Richard III, holds a sword in his right hand, which is raised above his head. In his left hand, which is by his side, he holds a scabbard.

In this depiction of Act 5, Scene 3 in Shakespeare's play Richard III, at least nine ghosts hover around the central figure of Richard III, their murderer. Directly below Richard, two small translucent figures hover or fly with heads at left, facing up, and bodies horizontal. They both have short, curly hair and appear to wear gowns; both point and look upward toward Richard and have open mouths. They are likely the ghosts of Prince Edward and Richard, Duke of York, the young sons of late King Edward IV, who in the play tell Richard: "Dream on thy cousins smothered in the Tower./ Let us be lead within thy bosom, Richard, And weigh thee down to ruin, shame, and death./ Thy nephews' souls bid thee despair and die." (155-158). Seen from behind and facing left, the foregrounded figure (who has curly hair) raises his left arm vertically and extends his right arm backward to touch his extended left leg.

In this depiction of Act 5, Scene 3 in Shakespeare's play Richard III, at least nine ghosts hover around the central figure of Richard III, their murderer. Directly below Richard, two small translucent figures hover or fly with heads at left, facing up, and bodies horizontal. They both have short hair and appear to wear gowns; both point and look upward toward Richard and have open mouths. They are likely the ghosts of Prince Edward and Richard, Duke of York, the young sons of late King Edward IV, who in the play tell Richard: "Dream on thy cousins smothered in the Tower./ Let us be lead within thy bosom, Richard, And weigh thee down to ruin, shame, and death./ Thy nephews' souls bid thee despair and die." (155-158). The prince behind his companion faces forward and raises his right arm vertically while his left is visible at his side.

In this depiction of Act 5, Scene 3 in Shakespeare's play Richard III, at least nine ghosts hover around the central figure of Richard III, their murderer. Four ghostly figures hover near the right margin. Facing away but turned to look left, a female figure with a long gown and veil extends her left arm to touch Richard on the shoulder. Her mouth is open, suggesting she is speaking. Her right leg is slightly bent and extended behind her with the right foot visible. This figure is likely the Ghost of Lady Anne, Richard's wife whom he murdered in order to court his niece, Elizabeth of York. In the play, she tells Richard: "Richard, thy wife, that wretched Anne thy wife,/ That never slept a quiet hour with thee,/ Now fills thy sleep with perturbations./ Tomorrow, in the battle, think on me,/ And fall thy edgeless sword. Despair and die!" (169-173).

In this depiction of Act 5, Scene 3 in Shakespeare's play Richard III, at least nine ghosts hover around the central figure of Richard III, their murderer. Four ghostly figures hover near the right margin. Immediately behind and to the left of Lady Anne, the female figure, an older male figure with a mustache and long beard who may wear a gown faces forward and looks down to the left toward the central figure, Richard. He bends his right arm to point toward Anne.

In this depiction of Act 5, Scene 3 in Shakespeare's play Richard III, at least nine ghosts hover around the central figure of Richard III, their murderer. Four ghostly figures hover near the right margin. The heads of two of these ghostly figures appear alternatively to the left of the bearded male figure and to the right of the female figure, Anne. The head at left faces forward and left to look toward the central figure, Richard.

In this depiction of Act 5, Scene 3 in Shakespeare's play Richard III, at least nine ghosts hover around the central figure of Richard III, their murderer. Four ghostly figures hover near the right margin. The heads of two of these ghostly figures appear alternatively to the left of the bearded male figure and to the right of the female figure, Anne. The gender of the head at right is unclear, but this figure faces directly forward.

In this depiction of Act 5, Scene 3 in Shakespeare's play Richard III, at least nine ghosts hover around the central figure of Richard III, their murderer. On the left side of the image, three additional ghostly male figures appear to hover, all facing right and leaning forward to look toward the central figure, Richard. The rightmost of these is bearded and wears a crown and a long gown. His mouth is open, perhaps to suggest he is speaking, and his brow furrowed in anger as he points accusingly toward bloody wounds in his chest with both bent arms. His left foot is visible below his gown. This is likely King Henry VI, who in the play tells Richard III, "When I was mortal, my annointed body/ By thee was punched full of deadly holes./Think on the Tower and me. Despair and die!" (132-134).

In this depiction of Act 5, Scene 3 in Shakespeare's play Richard III, at least nine ghosts hover around the central figure of Richard III, their murderer. On the left side of the image, three additional ghostly male figures appear to hover, all facing right and leaning forward to look toward the central figure, Richard. The middle male figure at left has short curly hair and appears to look down in horror at the wounds of the male figure in front of him, King Henry VI. He raises his bent right arm to his chest (where he appears to point) and may wear a gown. His mouth appears to be open.

In this depiction of Act 5, Scene 3 in Shakespeare's play Richard III, at least nine ghosts hover around the central figure of Richard III, their murderer. On the left side of the image, three additional ghostly male figures appear to hover, all facing right and leaning forward to look toward the central figure, Richard. Only the short-haired head of the leftmost figure, whose mouth is open, is visible.
Behind the figures in the upper half of the composition, the top of a tent is visible. In the play, the ghosts visit Richard in his battlefield tent on the eve of war.

In the lower half of the composition, in the background, there is a bed with sheets and a tubular pillow along with a table at left on which two lighted candles and what appears to be an open book rest. The light from the candles emphasizes the translucency of the ghosts at left.

Areas of dark shadow appear all around the composition, particularly in the corners. The darkness in the upper corners may suggest the time is night, which correlates with the nighttime setting of the scene in the play.

lg.note: Butlin 547.2 records additional inscriptions, but we have not been able to locate these on the work as it presently exists.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Three large figures, two female and one male, and twenty-four smaller female figures occupy the space of this composition, which represents The Vision of Queen Katharine in Act 4, Scene 2 of Shakespeare's play Henry VIII. The central female figure of Queen Katharine lies supine with legs together on a bed or couch with her head at right near the lower third of the scene. She has long hair and wears a gown and veil (perhaps also with a crown?). Both arms are bent by her sides but extended upward from the elbow with fingers spread. She appears to raise her head and shoulders away from the pillow below her, perhaps to better see the visionary activity above her. Queen Katharine is the wife of King Henry VIII who wishes to divorce her (as she has not born a male heir) and marry Anne Boleyn. Katharine becomes ill, and it is during her sickness in which The Vision occurs. The bed or couch on which she lies contains a serpentine arm at right as well as a pillow and heavy drapery on the left side. In front of the bed in both lower corners of the composition, the other two large figures sit facing each other on sizable pillows. Both have their eyes closed and appear to sleep with their heads supported on one bent arm. The figure in the right corner is a gowned female with long hair who rests her elbow on the open book atop the small table behind her. She is probably Patience, servant to the queen. The male figure at left has white hair and a long beard; he is also gowned. This is probably Griffith, the queen's usher. He rests his elbow on a similar table behind him and turns his head to face forward. The twenty-four other smaller figures in the scene, who all appear to be gowned and female, fly upward and around the supine figure of Queen Katharine in serpentine formations. Nine of these figures circle the body of Queen Katharine in the lower half of the image. In the center along the bottom margin, the lowest of these figures face forward but lean and face away from one another as they touch extended hands and perhaps also feet to form a sort of diamond shape between them. Both wear laurel crowns and wispy clouds are visible around them, as if arising from the same origin. The figure at right raises her left arm to hold the hand of a third figure who flies upward facing away. Both legs are bent and her long hair is visible. She raises her right hand to touch the foot of a fourth figure who flies or hovers directly to the right of Queen Katharine's head. This figure faces away but looks left. She wears a laurel crown and holds another such crown in her bent left arm. A fifth figure also holds this crown with her bent left arm while she hovers with body horizontal at left, just above the torso of Queen Katharine. Together, these small figures may be preparing to crown the supine queen, and both point upward with their other free hand. This moment is referenced directly in the play's text: "the first two [Personages] hold a spare garland over her head" (Act 4, Scene 2). Returning to the pair of figures at the bottom of the image, the left figure raises her right arm to hold the hand of a long-haired sixth figure at left who faces forward and raises both arms horizontally. This figure, with her right arm, touches (or almost touches) the foot of a seventh figure who faces away and twists her body to the right in a sort of half-circle around Queen Katharine's feet. This figure holds an object in each raised hand, which may be cymbals. Small clouds are visible beneath this figures at left. To the right of the leftmost figure's torso, two additional figures hover with bodies horizontal and complete the circle of figures around Queen Katharine. The leftmost of these faces forward and plays a harp or lyre. Her companion at right, who appears to wear a laurel crown, faces away and may also play a musical instrument. In the upper half of the image, fifteen figures fly upward or float on small, wispy clouds in a serpentine formation of three approximate tiers. The lowest tier contains four figures with bodies horizontal flying left and two furthest left whose bodies are slightly higher and twisted to the right. The rightmost figure faces forward with arms extended horizontally; in each hand, she holds circular objects that may be cymbals. Behind and slightly to the left of her, a second figure echoes her posture with arms raised horizontally, palms facing forward. The third figure from the right, who has long hair, faces to the left but turns to look back toward her companions. She plays a harp or lyre with her left hand. The fourth figure from the right faces away and holds a similar harp or lyre with bent arms. The two leftmost figures in this tier face away and bend sharply to the right with arms extended vertically; they both appear to hold and play cymbals. Four right-facing figures constitute the second and middle tier of figures. The leftmost figure, just to the right of the cymbal-playing pair below, has long hair and holds a harp or lyre with bent arms. To her right, a long-haired figure faces right and plays two horns, which she holds with extended arms. The rightmost figures in this tier fly upward side-by-side and play horns pointed upward. The figure at left faces away, and it is unclear which direction the figure at right faces. The third and highest tier contains five figures. The rightmost of these faces away and twists her body in a serpentine position to the left. To the left, a figure plays two horns, which she holds up with raised arms. The third figure from the right faces away but appears to turn her head to look right; she raises both arms vertically. The two leftmost figures are very close together and somewhat indistinguishable except for their heads, but they both appear to have their arms upward. Most of the scene's background sky contains colorful beams of light that appear to stream down from the upper margin of the image.

component.illusobjdesc: Three large figures, two female and one male, and twenty-four smaller female figures occupy the space of this composition, which represents The Vision of Queen Katharine in Act 4, Scene 2 of Shakespeare's play Henry VIII. The central female figure of Queen Katharine lies supine with legs together on a bed or couch with her head at right near the lower third of the scene. She has long hair and wears a gown and veil (perhaps also with a crown?). Both arms are bent by her sides but extended upward from the elbow with fingers spread. She appears to raise her head and shoulders away from the pillow below her, perhaps to better see the visionary activity above her. Her mouth may be open. This figure, Queen Katharine, is the wife of King Henry VIII who wishes to divorce her (as she has not born a male heir) and marry Anne Boleyn. Katharine becomes ill, and it is during her sickness in which The Vision occurs.
The bed or couch on which the central figure of Queen Katharine lies contains a serpentine arm or headboard at right as well as a pillow and heavy drapery on the left side.

In front of the bed in both lower corners of the composition, two large figures sit facing each other on sizable pillows. Both have their eyes closed and appear to sleep with their heads supported on one bent arm. The figure in the right corner is a gowned female with long hair who rests her right elbow on the open book atop the small table behind her. This is probably Patience, a servant to the queen. Her left arm is bent and crossed beneath her right. Her mouth may be open. Although her body faces left, her upper body is twisted to face forward. Her legs are extended and both feet (which are clad in shoes) are visible.

In front of the bed in both lower corners of the composition, two large figures sit facing each other on sizable pillows. Both have their eyes closed and appear to sleep with their heads supported on one bent arm. The male figure at left has white hair and a long beard; he is also gowned. This is probably Griffith, the queen's usher. He rests his left elbow on a table behind him and turns his head to face forward. His right arm is bent and by his side with his hand resting on his lap. His legs are bent and extended with one shoe-clad foot visible beneath his gown.

Two figures sit on large pillows in both lower corners of the image. These pillows each have a single tassel on one corner. A table is also visible in each corner, and both figures rest one arm on it. An open book rests on the table at right.

Twenty-four small, gowned female figures fly or hover in the scene. Nine of these figures form a circle around the body of Queen Katharine in the lower half of the image. In the center along the bottom margin, the two lowest of these figures face forward but lean and face away from one another as they touch extended hands and perhaps also feet to form a sort of diamond shape between them. Wispy clouds are visible around them, as if arising from the same origin. The figure at right (who may wear a crown or laurels?) raises her left arm to hold the hand of the figure above and right of her toward whom she also looks.

Twenty-four small, gowned female figures fly or hover in the scene. Nine of these figures form a circle around the body of Queen Katharine in the lower half of the image. In the center along the bottom margin, the two lowest of these figures face forward but lean and face away from one another as they touch extended hands and perhaps also feet to form a sort of diamond shape between them. Wispy clouds are visible around them, as if arising from the same origin. The figure at left who wears a crown of laurels raises her right arm to hold the hand of the figure above and left of her toward whom she also looks with her head up.

Twenty-four small, gowned female figures fly or hover in the scene. Nine of these figures form a circle around the body of Queen Katharine in the lower half of the image. Directly above and to the left of the sleeping female figure in the lower right corner, a female figure, who faces away and is thus seen from behind, flies up and to the right. She has long hair and may wear a laurel crown. Her left arm is at her side, and she holds the hand of the figure below her. Her right arm is extended upward, and she may touch the foot of the figure above her at right. The figure's legs are bent with the right extended backward and the bottom of her foot visible.

Twenty-four small, gowned female figures fly or hover in the scene. Nine of these figures form a circle around the body of Queen Katharine in the lower half of the image. Directly to the right of Queen Katharine's head, a fourth figure who flies or hovers directly to the right of Queen Katharine's head. Seen from behind, this figure faces away but looks left with right leg extended backward. She has long hair and wears a laurel crown; she holds another such crown in her bent left arm. A fifth figure also holds this crown and flies just above the torso of Queen Katharine. Together, these small figures may be preparing to crown the supine queen, and both point upward with their other free hand. This moment is referenced directly in the play's text: "the first two [Personages] hold a spare garland over her head" (Act 4, Scene 2).

Twenty-four small, gowned female figures fly or hover in the scene. Nine of these figures form a circle around the body of Queen Katharine in the lower half of the image. A fifth figure who flies or hovers directly above the torso of Queen Katharine bends both arms upward and points upward with her right hand. She faces forward but turns her head to the right, perhaps to look toward her companion at right. She appears to have short hair and may wear a laurel crown. Her legs are together and extended to the left horizontally. She holds a laurel crown with her bent left arm. The figure to her right also holds this crown. Together, these small figures may be preparing to crown the supine queen, and both point upward with their other free hand. This moment is referenced directly in the play's text: "the first two [Personages] hold a spare garland over her head" (Act 4, Scene 2).

Twenty-four small, gowned female figures fly or hover in the scene. Nine of these figures form a circle around the body of Queen Katharine in the lower half of the image. Returning to the central pair of figures at the bottom of the image, the left figure raises her right arm to hold the hand of the sixth figure above and at left. This figure faces forward and leans to the left with her head bent sharply to the right, perhaps to look down toward her companion. She has long hair. She raises her left arm horizontally and her right arm at 135 degrees. She appears to reach for and perhaps touch the foot of the figure above her at left.

Twenty-four small, gowned female figures fly or hover in the scene. Nine of these figures form a circle around the body of Queen Katharine in the lower half of the image. Directly left of Queen Katharine's feet, a seventh figure who faces away and is thus seen from behind bends her body to the right with both arms raised vertically and legs extended backward (with the left bent upward). She appears to have short hair. In each hand, she holds an object, perhaps a cymbal, which she may play. Small clouds are visible beneath this figures at left, and she may float on these.

Twenty-four small, gowned female figures fly or hover in the scene. Nine of these figures form a circle around the body of Queen Katharine in the lower half of the image. Two figures hover with bodies horizontal over the legs of Queen Katharine to complete the circle of figures around her. The leftmost of these faces forward and plays a harp or lyre, which she holds with bent arms. She has short hair. Both legs are extended to the left and together.

Twenty-four small, gowned female figures fly or hover in the scene. Nine of these figures form a circle around the body of Queen Katharine in the lower half of the image. Two figures hover with bodies horizontal over the legs of Queen Katharine to complete the circle of figures around her. The figure at right faces away and is thus seen from behind. She appears to have long hair (perhaps in a braid?) and wears some sort of crown or laurel wreath. Her legs are extended to the left and together. Her right arm is bent, and she appears to hold (and likely play) a harp or lyre visible to the right of her torso. Her head is turned to the left, perhaps to look back toward her companion.

Three figures in the lower group of figures that form a circle around the supine Queen Katharine play musical instruments: the leftmost figure near the queen's feet holds circular objects that may be cymbals and the two figures to her right hold and play a harp or (to the right) a harp or lyre.

Wispy clouds are visible near the smaller female figures in the lower half of the margin, where they appear to originate at the same central point where the two figures hover back to back. The clouds extend a short distance diagonally at right but at left rise near the middle of the left margin, terminating just above the feet of Queen Katharine.

In the upper half of the image, fifteen gowned female figures fly upward or float on small, wispy clouds in a serpentine formation of three approximate tiers. The lowest tier contains four figures with bodies horizontal flying left and two additional figures at left whose bodies are slightly higher and twisted to the right. The rightmost figure faces forward with arms extended horizontally; in each hand, she holds circular objects that may be cymbals, which she may play. She has long hair and her mouth may be open. Her head is turned slightly to the right and her legs may be crossed at the ankles.

In the upper half of the image, fifteen gowned female figures fly upward or float on small, wispy clouds in a serpentine formation of three approximate tiers. The lowest tier contains four figures with bodies horizontal flying left and two additional figures at left whose bodies are slightly higher and twisted to the right. Behind and slightly to the left of the rightmost figure, a second figure echoes her posture with arms raised horizontally, palms facing up. She has long hair and leans her head slightly to the left. She appears to frown.

component.characteristic: In the upper half of the image, fifteen gowned female figures fly upward or float on small, wispy clouds in a serpentine formation of three approximate tiers. The lowest tier contains four figures with bodies horizontal flying left and two additional figures at left whose bodies are slightly higher and twisted to the right. The third figure from the right, who has long hair, faces to the left but turns to look back toward her companions. She plays a harp or lyre with her left hand; both arms are bent upward to hold the instrument. Her legs are extended and appear to be together.

component.illusobjdesc: In the upper half of the image, fifteen gowned female figures fly upward or float on small, wispy clouds in a serpentine formation of three approximate tiers. The lowest tier contains four figures with bodies horizontal flying left and two additional figures at left whose bodies are slightly higher and twisted to the right. The fourth figure from the right faces away but turns her head to look right; she and holds a similar harp or lyre with bent arms. She appears to have short hair. Her gown, which is quite transparent, is only apparent by the serpentine fold of drapery below her left foot.

In the upper half of the image, fifteen gowned female figures fly upward or float on small, wispy clouds in a serpentine formation of three approximate tiers. The lowest tier contains four figures with bodies horizontal flying left and two additional figures at left whose bodies are slightly higher and twisted to the right. The two leftmost figures in this tier face away and bend sharply to the right with arms extended vertically; they both appear to hold and play tambourines. Their legs are extended and together.

Four of the five figures in the lowest tier of gowned female figures who fly or hover in the upper half of the composition hold musical instruments. The rightmost figure holds what appear to be cymbals; the third and fourth figures from the right holds and perhaps play lyres; and the two leftmost figures whose bodies are twisted to the right both hold and play tambourines.

Four right-facing female figures constitute the second and middle tier of gowned female figures who fly or hover in the upper half of the composition. The leftmost figure, just to the right of the cymbal-playing pair below, has long hair and holds or perhaps plays a harp or lyre with bent arms. With body horizontal, she turns her head to look forward and her long hair streams behind her. Her right leg is visibly extended behind her.

Four right-facing female figures constitute the second and middle tier of figures, who fly or hover in the upper half of the composition. The third figure from the right, whose body is horizontal, has long hair and faces right. She plays two horns or trumpets, which she holds with extended arms. Both legs are extended behind her and together. She may be nude or wear a transparent gown.

Four right-facing female figures constitute the second and middle tier of figures, who fly or hover in the upper half of the composition. The two rightmost figures in this tier fly upward side-by-side with bodies twisted to the left. They play horns or trumpets pointed upward that they hold with bent arms raised vertically. Both may be nude or wear transparent gowns. The figure at left has short hair and turns her head to look up and right. Her legs are extended and together, though her right leg may be bent.

Four right-facing female figures constitute the second and middle tier of figures, who fly or hover in the upper half of the composition. The two rightmost figures in this tier fly upward side-by-side with bodies twisted to the left. They play horns or trumpets pointed upward that they hold with bent arms raised vertically. Both may be nude or wear transparent gowns. The rightmost figure appears to face forward with head bent back to face up, but this is not clear.

In the second, middle tier of figures who fly or hover in the upper half of the composition, all four hold, and likely play, musical instruments. The leftmost figure holds a lyre; the second figure from the left plays two horns or trumpets; and the two rightmost figures whose bodies are twisted up and to the left both play single horns or trumpets.

The third and highest tier of figures in the upper half of the composition contains five female(?) figures who fly or hover. The rightmost figure faces away and bends her body in a serpentine position to the left. She may be nude or wear a transparent gown. Her arms are extended vertically and her legs, which are together, are extended backward, perhaps with knees bent. She may hold an indistinguishable object, likely a musical instrument.

The third and highest tier of figures in the upper half of the composition contains five female(?) figures who fly or hover. The second figure from the right, who is gowned, faces away and slightly left. She plays two horns or trumpets, which she holds up with raised arms (the left arm is bent). Her legs are together and extended backward (and horizontally) at right.

The third and highest tier of figures in the upper half of the composition contains five female(?) figures who fly or hover. The third figure from the right, who is gowned, faces away but appears to turn her head to look right; she raises both arms vertically. Her legs are together and extended backward.

The third and highest tier of figures in the upper half of the composition contains five female(?) figures who fly or hover. The two leftmost figures who are both gowned are very close together and somewhat indistinguishable except for their heads, but they both appear to have their arms raised upward. The figure at right may face left.

The third and highest tier of figures in the upper half of the composition contains five female(?) figures who fly or hover. The two leftmost figures who are both gowned are very close together and somewhat indistinguishable except for their heads, but they both appear to have their arms raised upward. The figure at left faces away and extends at least one leg behind her at right.

The second figure from the right in the highest tier of figures in the upper half of the composition holds and plays two horns or trumpets. The other figures in this tier may hold instruments as well, but these are less distinct.
Most of the scene's background sky contains colorful beams of light that appear to stream down from the upper margin of the image.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Standing on tiptoe at right, a male figure surrounded by a whitish-blue cloud looks down at a second male figure at left who sits at a table and holds an open book but turns to look toward the first figure. An illustration of Shakespeare's play Julius Caesar, this scene represents Act 4, Scene 3, in which the Ghost of Caesar visits Brutus in his tent to tell him they will meet again at Philippi as an omen of Brutus' impending death. The Ghost of Caesar at right wears a long gown and laurel crown above short hair. His face is turned down and his mouth is open. His right arm is raised vertically and he holds a sword pointing up. His left arm is raised at 135 degrees with fingers spread in a gesture of pointing to the left. His left leg is extended backward, though with his foot still on the ground. The cloud enveloping him attests to his ghostly state. The figure of Brutus at left sits on a low chair in front of a table on which two lit candles stand. He holds an open book with his bent right arm, which rests on the table. His left arm is raised at 135 degrees; he points to the left with his left index finger. His upper body faces away but he turns his head and lower body to face right, with his left leg extended and right leg bent beside the chair. He wears a shirt, tights or pants(?), and sandals. His mouth is open and his short curly hair appears to stand on end. Two additional tiny forms appear in the space between the main figures' feet lower right. Although the details of these are indistinguishable, these may be human figures. The one at right who may face left wears a dark gown and a large headdress and perhaps holds a linear object in its left hand. The figure at left who may face right wears a lighter gown. Alternatively, the figure at right could be the shadow of the figure at left. The spine of a second book and the serpentine flourish of a bed's scroll are visible against the left margin. Dark pockets of shadow appear throughout the lower left quadrant.

component.illusobjdesc: Standing on tiptoe at right, a male figure surrounded by a whitish-blue cloud looks down at a second male figure at left who sits at a table. An illustration of Shakespeare's play Julius Caesar, this scene represents Act 4, Scene 3, in which the Ghost of Caesar visits Brutus in his tent to tell him they will meet again at Philippi as an omen of Brutus' impending death. The Ghost of Caesar at right wears a long gown and laurel crown above short hair. His face is turned down and his mouth is open; he may be speaking. His right arm is raised vertically and he holds a sword pointing up. His left arm is raised at 135 degrees with fingers spread in a gesture of pointing to the left. His left leg is extended backward, though with his foot still on the ground. He may wear a shoe on his left foot.
The cloud enveloping the figure at right, the Ghost of Caesar, attests to his ghostly state and perhaps also his sudden apparition.

Standing on tiptoe at right, a male figure surrounded by a whitish-blue cloud looks down at a second male figure at left who sits at a table. An illustration of Shakespeare's play Julius Caesar, this scene represents Act 4, Scene 3, in which the Ghost of Caesar visits Brutus in his tent to tell him they will meet again at Philippi as an omen of Brutus' impending death. The figure of Brutus at left sits on a low chair in front of a table. He holds an open book with his bent right arm, which rests on the table. His left arm is raised at 135 degrees; he points to the left with his left index finger. His upper body faces away but he turns his head and lower body to face right, with his left leg extended and right leg bent beside the chair. He wears a shirt, tights or pants(?), and sandals. His mouth is open (he may be speaking) and his short curly hair appears to stand on end.

The figure at left, Brutus, sits on a low chair, which is set atop a low rectangular plinth or platform. A table is visible in front of him on which two lit candles in candlesticks sit. Brutus hold an open book, which rests on the table. Near the left margin, the spine of a second book is visible below the serpentine flourish of a scroll(?).

Two additional tiny forms, possibly human figures, appear in the space between the main figures' feet lower right. Although the details of these are indistinguishable, the figure at right who may face left wears a dark gown and a large hat/headdress and perhaps holds a linear object in its left hand. The figure at left who may face right wears a lighter gown. Alternatively, the figure at right could be the shadow of the figure at left.

Two additional tiny forms, possibly human figures, appear in the space between the main figures' feet lower right. Although the details of these are indistinguishable, the figure at left who may face right wears a light-colored gown and perhaps also a hat.
Two additional tiny figures appear in the space between the main figures' feet lower right. The figure at right could be the shadow of the figure at left, as suggested by its dark form.
Dark pockets of shadow appear throughout the lower left quadrant.

lg.note: Butlin 547.4 records additional inscriptions, but we have not been able to locate these on the work as it presently exists.

desc.objtitle: Hamlet and His Father's Ghost, Object 5 (Butlin 547.5)

illustration.illusobjdesc: Two figures, one standing at left and one kneeling at right, face each other in a barren, cloudy landscape. This scene represents the encounter in Shakespeare's play Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 5, of Hamlet with the Ghost of his father, the previous king of Denmark, who describes his murder at the hands of Claudius, Hamlet's uncle and new king, and demands that Hamlet avenge the killing. Hamlet, the figure at right, kneels facing left with head up to look at the Ghost. His mouth is open in surprise or fear and his short hair is standing on end. He wears a shirt, breeches or tights, shoes, and a fur-lined cloak. His sword is visible by his left hip. He bends both arms and his hands are raised with palms facing out and left. He bends forward slightly. The Ghost of his father stands facing forward and right with head down at left. He bends slightly to the right. He wears a full suit of armor and a helmet. His eyes are opened widely, and he has a mustache and long beard. His arms are straight and by his sides with fingers extended downward. Blue beams of light, or perhaps fire, emerge from his feet or the ground on which he stands. These, coupled with the barren landscape, may represent the daily existence of the Ghost, which he describes: "I am thy father's spirit/ Doomed for a certain term to walk the night/ And for the day confined to fast in fires/ Till the foul crimes done in my days of nature/ Are burnt and purged away" (14-18). Indeed, the darkness of the background sky and clouds, parted only slightly to make the moon visible at right, suggest the time in night.

component.illusobjdesc: Two figures, one standing at left and one kneeling at right, face each other in a barren, cloudy landscape. This scene represents the encounter in Shakespeare's play Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 5, of Hamlet with the Ghost of his father, the previous king of Denmark, who describes his murder at the hands of Claudius, Hamlet's uncle and new king, and demands that Hamlet avenge the killing. Hamlet, the figure at right, kneels facing left with head up to look at the Ghost. His mouth is open in surprise or fear and his short hair is standing on end. He wears a shirt, breeches or tights, shoes, and a fur-lined cloak. His sword is visible by his left hip. He bends both arms and his hands are raised with palms facing out and left. He bends forward slightly.
A sword in its scabbard is visible pointing down and to the right beside the left hip of the kneeling figure at right, Hamlet.

Two figures, one standing at left and one kneeling at right, face each other in a barren, cloudy landscape. This scene represents the encounter in Shakespeare's play Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 5, of Hamlet with the Ghost of his father, the previous king of Denmark, who describes his murder at the hands of Claudius, Hamlet's uncle and new king, and demands that Hamlet avenge the killing. The Ghost of his father stands facing forward and right with head down at left, perhaps to look toward Hamlet at right. He bends slightly to the right. He wears a full suit of armor and a helmet. His eyes are opened widely, and he has a mustache and long beard. His arms are straight and by his sides with fingers extended downward.

Blue beams of light, or perhaps fire, emerge from the feet of the figure at left, the Ghost of Hamlet's father, or the ground on which he stands. These, coupled with the barren landscape, may represent the daily existence of the Ghost, which he describes: "I am thy father's spirit/ Doomed for a certain term to walk the night/ And for the day confined to fast in fires/ Till the foul crimes done in my days of nature/ Are burnt and purged away" (Act 1, Scene 5, 14-18).
Two figures, one standing at left and one kneeling at right, face each other in a barren, cloudy landscape.

The darkness of the background sky and clouds, parted only slightly to make the moon visible at right, suggest the time is night. This corresponds to the Ghost's explanation that he is "doomed for a certain term to walk the night" (Act 1, Scene 5, 15).

desc.objtitle: As If An Angel Dropped Down From The Clouds, Object 6 (Butlin 547.6)

illustration.illusobjdesc: A nude female figure reclines while reading on a cloud above a nude male figure who faces down while hovering in midair. He raises his arms vertically and holds a length of rope in his right hand. Directly below the male figure, a horse rears its front legs while its back legs stand on a portion of rock or cliff visible lower right. Beams of light extend outward from a sun in the lower left corner. This scene illustrates Shakespeare's simile in Act 4, Scene 1 of Henry IV, Part I, in which Vernon describes the young Prince Henry (Harry) before battle: "I saw young Harry with his beaver on,/ His cuisses on this thighs, gallantly armed,/ Rise from the ground like feathered Mercury/ And vaulted with such ease into his seat/ As if an angel [dropped] down from the clouds,/ To turn and wind a fiery Pegasus/ And witch the world with noble horsemanship." (110-116). Thus the central figure represents this angel and the horse, Pegasus.

component.illusobjdesc: A nude female figure reclines while reading on a cloud above a nude male figure who faces down while hovering in midair above a rearing horse. Lying on her right side facing forward, she crosses her left leg over her right and bends both arms in front of her chest where they rest on the open book in front of her. She has long hair and turns her head down, perhaps to look toward the male figure and horse below or at her book.
A nude female figure reclines on a cloud while reading (and resting her arms on) an open book.
A nude female figure reclines on a cloud in the upper middle of the composition.

In the center of the illustration, a nude male figure who faces down while hovering or flying in midair looks toward the horse rearing beneath him. He has short hair and extends both legs, which are spread, backward, with his lower body twisted to face forward. His genitals are prominent. He raises his arms vertically and holds a length of rope in his right hand. The image literally illustrates a simile in Act 4, Scene 1 of Shakespeare's Henry IV, Part I, in which Vernon describes the young Prince Henry (Harry) before battle: "I saw young Harry with his beaver on,/ His cuisses on this thighs, gallantly armed,/ Rise from the ground like feathered Mercury/ And vaulted with such ease into his seat/ As if an angel [dropped] down from the clouds,/ To turn and wind a fiery Pegasus/ And witch the world with noble horsemanship." (110-116). Thus the male figure represents this angel.

The nude male figure in this image holds a length of rope in his right hand that forms a circle beneath his extended body. It is likely the tool Prince Henry would use in the illustrated simile in order "To turn and wind a fiery Pegasus" in Act 4, Scene 1 of Shakespeare's Henry IV, Part I (115).

In the lower half of the image, a horse rears its extended front legs while its back legs stand on a portion of rock or land visible lower right. Although the horse faces left, its head is raised to look up. Its mane and tail flow animatedly. The animal is likely the "fiery Pegasus" mentioned in the simile in Act 4, Scene 1 of Shakespeare's Henry IV, Part I (115).
An outcropping of stone or a rocky cliff on which the rear legs of the horse balance is visible in the lower right corner of the scene.
A circular sun is visible in the lower left corner of the illustration.
The sun visible in the lower left corner radiates beams of light across the lower two thirds of the composition, in which the coloring of the background sky suggests sunrise or sunset.
